Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description:
Nick Van Exel hasn't gone anywhere despite his
trade demand, and for that the Denver Nuggets are grateful.
article.headline: Denver rallies to go 2-0 without Issel

images.name: Van Exel, Nick 011215 inline
images.caption: Denver Nuggets guard Nick Van Exel scored 11 in the fourth quarter.

article.linkText: Nuggets' Van Exel right at home in fourth quarter
article.story:
DENVER (AP) -- Nick Van Exel hasn't gone anywhere despite his trade demand, and for that the Denver Nuggets are grateful. Van Exel scored 11 of his 24 points in the fourth quarter, and the Nuggets outscored Phoenix 17-2 over the final four minutes to rally for a 106-98 victory Saturday night. "In those situations, I want to have the ball in my hands and look for my shot," Van Exel said. "I've made some big shots down the stretch. It's a blessing, I guess. "When those situations arise, I feel I can pull us out of it. I'm really not afraid of failing. That's the most important thing: You can't be afraid of failing." Phoenix coach Scott Skiles agreed. "Van Exel is fearless out there," Skiles said. "He can make big plays." Raef LaFrentz and Voshon Lenard added 19 points apiece as the Nuggets won for the second time in as many games under interim coach Mike Evans, who was subbing for suspended coach Dan Issel. Stephon Marbury led Phoenix with 27 points. Rodney Rogers had 18 and Anfernee Hardaway 16. Denver outscored Phoenix 30-15 in the final period, erasing a 12-point deficit after Rogers' third consecutive basket put the Suns up 94-82 with 6:58 remaining. LaFrentz had eight points in the final period, including a pair of 3-pointers that ignited the Nuggets' surge. After Hardaway's short jumper made it 96-89 with 4:12 left, the Nuggets ran off 10 consecutive points, including 3-pointers by LaFrentz and Van Exel and two free throws by Van Exel. Another basket by Hardaway cut the Denver lead to 99-98, but Van Exel countered with an 18-foot jumper with 1:14 to go. After a shot-clock violation on the Suns, Lenard hit a 3-pointer with 30 seconds left. Rogers missed a 3-point try, and Van Exel made two foul shots with nine seconds left. "We dug deep tonight, we didn't give up," Van Exel said. "We were down and we kept fighting, which is different. Usually when we get down in the fourth period, we find a way to lose." A key strategy, according to Van Exel, was to contain Marbury in the fourth quarter "and make the other guys beat us." Marbury didn't score in the final period and got off only one shot. Evans said his team played with "energy, focus and a will to win. You can see how fired up our guys are right now." Referring to Issel, Evans said, "I miss the big fella. I miss his energy, I miss his sense of humor, especially during tight moments. He's got a great way to relieve tension." Marbury said the Suns "let this one get away. I think we got comfortable with the big lead we had. We got kind of lax. Our defense at the end was poor, and Nick made some tough shots." Marbury had 14 points in the first quarter, including nine in the last two minutes, as Phoenix opened a five-point lead. Marbury had two driving layups and a three-point play during his flurry. The Suns scored the first seven points of the second quarter -- six by Tony Delk -- to take a 36-24 lead. Calbert Cheaney had three consecutive Denver baskets, and James Posey hit a pair of 3-pointers to help rally the Nuggets. Marbury's 3-pointer padded the Suns' lead to 10, but Van Exel scored his only five points of the half in the final 33 seconds as Denver cut the halftime deficit to 54-50. Denver reclaimed the lead for the first time since the opening period as Van Exel hit a 3-pointer and Lenard an 18-footer for a 63-60 advantage early in the third quarter. But Phoenix bounced back with a 19-7 surge sparked by Jake Voskuhl, who didn't play in the first half but had 11 points and six rebounds in the third period. Voskuhl's layup and Marbury's 21-footer made it 81-72 late in the period, and Marbury's reverse driving layup put the Suns ahead 83-76 entering the final quarter. Game notes
Issel served the second game of a four-game suspension without pay for making an insensitive ethnic remark to a fan after a game against Charlotte on Tuesday. ... Suns forward Tom Gugliotta missed his third consecutive game because of a strained left quadriceps. ... Phoenix forward Bo Outlaw suffered a cut on the top of his head when fouled by LaFrentz late in the second quarter, but he returned. ... Denver is 2-0 against the Suns this season but has won just three of the past 19 meetings. ... The Nuggets hadn't scored 100 or more points in their previous 12 games.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
